did.abstract: Program Director at the Ark, Ann Arbor, Michigan music club; administrative records relating to the management of the Ark, including artists’ contracts and financial records, printed materials such as concert calendars, flyers, and posters, and photographs of Ark performances, informal snapshots and publicity photos of performers.

repository.corpname: Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

acqinfo.p: The papers were donated by Dave Siglin (donor no. 10045) in 2008.

accruals.p: Periodic additions to the papers are expected.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open to research.

userestrict.p: Copyright is not held by the Regents of the University of Michigan.

prefercite.p: [item], folder, box, Dave Siglin papers, Bentley Historical Library, University of Michigan

bioghist.p: Dave Siglin served as Program Director for the Ark, an Ann Arbor music venue from 1968 until his retirement in March of 2008.

The Ark was established in 1965 as an outreach ministry--a coffeehouse--by five local churches: Northside Presbyterian Church, First Presbyterian Church, Calvary Presbyterian Church, Campus Chapel, and Presbyterian Campus Center. Though the Ark began as a partnership between religious organizations, the purpose of the Ark was not evangelism. Rather, the Ark founders wanted to provide university students with a safe, substance-free space where music, discussion, and artistic expression could thrive, and a respite from the turbulent campus climate of the mid 1960s. The Ark's mission statement is as follows: "The Ark is a non-profit organization dedicated to the enrichment of the human spirit through the presentation, preservation and encouragement of folk, roots and ethnic music and related arts. The Ark provides a safe and welcoming atmosphere for all people to listen to, learn about, perform and share music."

Under Siglin's management, the Ark became a folk music institution, with many of the major folk artists of the 1960s-2000s performing at the Ark. Folk music continues to be one of the many musical styles presented at the Ark. Since its inception in 1965, the Ark has had three different homes: the first at the former Adams House at 1421 Hill Street. During the late 1970s, funding from the Ark's founding churches was discontinued and the Ark was reorganized as 501(3) non-profit organization; shortly after the reorganization, the Ark moved to its second site at 637 1/2 S. Main Street. The Ark opened at its the current location at 316 S. Main Street in 1996.
The Ark continues to provide public music events as a non-profit organization. Anya Siglin, Dave and Linda Siglin's daughter is currently the Ark's Program Director.

scopecontent.p: The Dave Siglin papers date from 1968-2008 and primarily document Siglin's management role at the Ark, an Ann Arbor music club. The papers have been arranged into three series: Administrative Records; Printed Materials; and Photographs.

Administrative Records contain artists' contracts for musicians who performed at the Ark, financial records, and a 1976 contract between the City of Ann Arbor and Dave Siglin that addresses the Ark's newly acquired non-profit status. The series also includes correspondence addressed to Dave and Linda Siglin. Financial records are part of this series and are most comprehensive for 1969 until the early 1970s, though scattered dates are represented in the collection. An oversized financial ledger also comprises part of this series.

did.unittitle: Ann Arbor Comprehensive Employment Program, Ark Coffeehouse and City of Ann Arbor 1976

odd.p: (Incoming correspondence to Dave and Linda Siglin)

scopecontent.p: Printed Materials contain monthly concert calendars from 1969-1982, bi-monthly event calendars from 1984-2008, concert flyers from 1969, 1972-1976, a news clipping file with various articles about the Ark, and miscellaneous printed matter. An outsized volume contains concert posters and flyers from 1978-1986.

did.unittitle: Ark Bimonthly Calendar of Events October 1984-December 2004
Ark Bimonthly Calendar of Events 2005-2008 (scattered dates)
Patrons of the Ark and list of benefit performers

scopecontent.p: Photographs contain images of performers and audiences during Ark concerts. Candid shots are included as well. There are two folders of photographs depicting Dave and Linda Siglin. Separate from photographs taken at the Ark are the publicity photos produced by performers’ publicists and distributed for use in press and publicity materials. Photographs are arranged alphabetically. When the item contains the note "see also" this means that another image of that performer is contained among the images of another performer. The bulk of the photographs date from the early 1970s until the late 1980s.
